Subjects: Dunbar, battle of; occasional verse; historical poems
Bibliographic Ghosts:
Lincoln, Lincoln Cathedral Library: a ghost?: removed by Robbins and Cutler (1965)
XRossell Hope Robbins, and John L. Cutler. Supplement to the Index of Middle English Verse. Lexington, Kentucky: University of Kentucky Press, 1965; London, British Library Royal 20 A.II: not found in this MS.
_description: Song on the victory of the English at Dunbar inserted in Peter Langtoft’s Chronicle and Robert Mannyng of Brunne’s Chronicle — one 12-line stanza, aabccbddeffe

BodFair24.First Lines:
Wol worþe swich a fot folkþat drof þe skottes in
                    þe polk…
BodFair24.Last Lines:
…þe deuel i þou bikenneþat ragged rit in
                    helle
BodFair24.Editions:
Wright,  Thomas,
                        ed.  
             The Political Songs of England.
Camden Society
         o.s. 6 (1839): 394-5; 295-6.

OxfAllS39.Transcription:
Þe fote folk put þe scottes in þe polk an naked þaire
                    nagesbe waye herd i nauer seye of prestere pagesTo pike þe robes
                    of þe Rige þat in feld felleÞat token ay tulke þe roghe
                    raggy schulke rugham to helle
OxfAllS39.Note:
Written as four lines; in Langtoft’s
                    Chronicle.

CULGg11.First Lines:
þe fote folkeputh þe scotes in þe polkeand
                    wakned þaire nages…

Wright,  Thomas,
                        ed.  
             The Political Songs of England.
Camden Society
         o.s. 6 (1839): 394-5; 295-6.

                    polk…

BLHar114.Transcription:
Þe fote folkPutte scottes in þe polkAnd nakkned
                    þare nagesBy waye herd i neuere sayeOf prester pagesTo pike
                    þe Robes of þe Rikeand in þe dike schonneÞikkin
                    scot of Aberlythin Clut es ty honne
BLHar114.Note:
In Langtoft’s Chronicle. First two lines written two lines
                    of verse in one line of MS.

BLRoy20Axi.Transcription:
Þe fot folk . þat þe scottis in þe polk . & nakid
                    þeir nagesBe wai . her I neuere sai . of prestere pagesTo pike .
                    þe robes of þe rike . and in þe dik sonneÞou wiffin .
                    scot of abrenityn . cloutid is þi houne
BLRoy20Axi.Note:
Several verse lines per manuscript line. In Langtoft’s
                        Chronicle.

CollArmsAr14.Transcription:
Wel wrþ swich a fote folkÞat put þe scottes in þe
                    polkand paied þeim þeir wagesBi wode ne bi weieHerd I
                    neuere seieof prestere pagesTo pulle and to pikeþe roles of
                    þe rikeþat in þe feld felleHou ferd þe
                    wrecches þenneþe deuel i þem bikenneþat ragged sit
                    in helle
CollArmsAr14.Note:
Variant version; in Langtoft’s Chronicle. First letter
                    offset; couplets with a tail rhyme offset.
CollArmsAr14.Editions:
Wright,  Thomas,
                        ed.  
             The Political Songs of England.
Camden Society
         o.s. 6 (1839): 394-5; 295-6.

CollArmsAr61.Transcription:
Þe fote folkPutte þe scottes in þe polkAnd
                    nalkend þair uagesBy way herd i neuer say Of prester pagesTo pike
                    þe robes of þe rike and in þe dike eþonneWiffyn scot of
                    Abernithin clut es ty houne

InnerTem5117.First Lines:
Oure fote folk put þam in þe polk & nakned þer
                        uagesbi no way herd I neuer say of prester pagespurses
                    to pike robis to rike & in dike þam schouneþou wiffin scotte
                    of Abrethin kotte is þi houne
